div3.head:
Hdq'rs co I, 1st Gen't
reserve forces of Virginia
div3.p: This company will meet at its usual rendezvous this (Tuesday) evening, June 14, at 6 o'clock.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. W. R. Drickard.
P. J. Wright, O. S. je 14--1t

div3.head:
Headquarters reserve forces of Va,
Richmond, June 7, 1864.
div3.p:
General Orders, No. 2.--All persons belonging to the reserve forces of Virginia, who have waited to report at their proper rendezvous for duty, in compliance with General Orders No. 1, issued from these headquarters, May 16th, 1864, calling them into the field, are now, for the last time, notified and required to join their respective companies without delay.
Upon the failure of absentees to report for duty, within a reasonable time after the publication of this order enrolling officers will be instructed to arrest them and turn them over in conformity to law, to the camps of instruction for assignment to permanent, service with the active forces, as if they were between the ages of eighteen and forty five.
div3.closer:
By command of Brig. Gen. Kemper.
R. H. Catleft, A. A. G. je 9--1w

div3.head: Three hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, about 10 or 12 days ago, from Mr. C. H. Bullington's, near Staples's Mill, in Henrico, where he was hired, my negro man Alfred.
Said negro is of dark brown color, about 22 years old, 5 feet 10 or 11 inches in height, has a down look, and stammers when spoken to. I will give the above reward for his apprehension and confinement in any jail so that I can get him, or his delivery to
div3.closer:
W. G. Miller,
Corner Clay and Adams sts. je 14--4t*

div3.head: 100 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on Saturday last, a negro fellow named Jim, 21 years of age, dark complexion, 5 feet 10 inches in height, and has the Provost Marshal's pass for ten days, dated 27th May.
I will pay the above reward for his return to me at Hungary, or for his confinement in jail.

div3.head: Ran away.
div3.p:
--From Charleston, S. C, the boy Horace.
He is a bright mulatto, sandy hair, about 5 feet 6 inches high, quick spoken, and smiles when spoken to, showing a good set of teeth.
He has been seen in Richmond and the camps in the vicinity; was in Richmond on the 9th inst. A reward of $100 will be paid for his delivery in Richmond jail.
He belongs to Dr. J. R. Solomons, Charleston.
Apply to.
div3.closer:
J. T. Solomons,
20th S. C. reg't, Kershaw's brigade. je 13--3t*

div3.head: 500 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from Mr. Anderson Willis, on the 9th of May, from Yanceyville, Caswell county, N. C, a negro man named Wm. Isaac, about 27 or 28 years old, of a dark gingerbread color, about 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high.
Said negro was bought from Mary C. Clarke, of Chesterfield county, Va, and has some relatives living in Prince Edward county.
He has been living with Mrs. Clarke, near Coalfield, for some time.
I will pay the above reward of $500 for the arrest and delivery of said negro to Mr. Robt. Lumpkin, Richmond.
Va

div3.head: 50 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my farm, near White Oak Swamp bridge, my negro boy Mitchell.
Said negro is about 18 years old, black, five feet high, has a scar over the left temple; had on when last seen a slouched hat and black woolen pants; supposed to be lurking about Richmond.
The above reward will be given if delivered at my farm, or Mr. Jack Fisher's.
div3.closer:
Loftin D. Allen,
Henrico county. je 10--eod3t*.

div3.head: 500 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--My boy Bartlott absconded from the Government blacksmith shop on the 5th instant.
He has a dark brown skin, about 19 years of age, 5 feet 6 inches high, is a bright and intelligent boy, and I think will endeavor to reach the Yankee lines.
I will pay the above reward for his return to me at the office of John C. Maynard, Major and Q M, corner 9th and Main sts.

div3.head: Ranaway.
div3.p:
--From my residence, on Fulton Hill, my negro man Phillip.
He is about 85 years old, 5 feet 2 or 3 inches high, dark complexion, slender built, and speaks quickly.
I will pay a reward of three hundred dollars for his return.

div3.head: Two hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my farm, in Henrico county, on Sunday, June 5th, my negro man Philip.
He is about 30 years of age, 5 feet 7 or 9 inches high, dark gingerbread complexion, wears a beard, good form, and of genteel appearance.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to me, or for his arrest, so that I can get him.

div3.head:
Confederate States of America.
Navy Department,
Richmond, June 24, 1864.
div3.p: All warrant officers and all petty officers, seamen, ordinary seamen, landed, boys, firemen, coal has core, and all employees of every description, and all the vessels and material of every description, belonging to the Navy, shall be considered as transferred to the Provisional Navy.
div3.closer:
By command of the President.
S. R. Mallory,
Secretary of the Navy. je 9--2taw1m.

div3.p: To the Friends of the Soldiers throughout Confederacy.--

opener.dateline: Quartermaster Gen'ls Department, Railroad Burral Richmond, Feb. 20, 1864.

div4.p: The friends and relatives of soldiers in the army of Northern Virginia are hereby notified that arrangement has this day been effected with Southern Express Company to carry all packages food and wearing apparel to Richmond, Va.,
To secure the advantage thus obtained that the Express Company, the following instruction must be observed:
Packages must not contain more than dred pounds be well secured and plainly and sent at the expense of the shipper to the Soldiers' Relief Associations, which are as follows:
In North Carolina, at Raleigh; in South at Columbia, in Georgia at Augusta; in Alabama at Montgomery; or to any other point at of these Associations have an office.

The Agents of these Association will there charge of them and ship daily by Southern Company to the proper Agents of the reward State at Richmond, who will see them district to the proper individual owners.

To meet the wishes of the soldiers, and them a certain and speedy communication home, the Southern Express Company has to give this freight preference over and, in order that no obstacle may occur to the access of so landable an enterprise, the road companies are hereby requested to Express Company such facilities as will enable make this arrangement a complete success.

As the Southern Express Company responsibility of the transportation of these ages, the Relief Associations are requested to draw their Agents who have heretofore travelling messengers.
If the Relief will establish agencies in the rear of other they may enjoy the same privileges hereby to the Army of Northern Virginia.
div4.closer:
F. W. Sirs
Lieut. Col. and Quartermaster
Approved: A. R. Lawton
Quartermaster

div4.head:
Quartermaster General's Dep't
Richmond, June 1st, 1864
div4.p: Mr. R. H. Bullock, an agent of this Department assigned to the duty of organizing the transportation of supplies of foot and clothing under arrangement with the Southern Express Company as above related.
He will visit the several Relief Association plain the working of the system, and friends of soldiers to take advantage of the way of supplying the wants of those in the

div4.head:
Office Southern Express Company
Augusta, Ga, Feb. 25, 1864.
div4.p: The Southern Express Company hereby our friends and relatives of soldiers in the Northern Virginia and elsewhere that they parel to carry out arrangements as the above card, and that they will do all power to fulfill is requirements.

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia
div3.p:
--A proclamation.--Whereas, the Court county of King and Queen has been the public enemy, and for that reason the holding the said court has heretofore been to be held at the house of Thomas Pace's Chapel, in said county, and the county having requested that for the gress of the people the place changed.
Therefore, I, William Smith of the Commonwealth of Virginia, require the justices composing the county said county, hereafter to hold its session town of Stevensville, in said county, and wise required by law.
Given under my hand of Government under the less seat of the Commonwealth at Richmond, this eighteenth day 1864, and in the 88th year of the Commonwealth
div3.closer:
Wm. Smith.
By the Governor:
Geo. W. Munford,
Sec'y. of the Commonwealth. my 19--c3t
